distributions: “A word can contain several morphemes which are separated by a hyphen in the transcription. The first morpheme determines the tone of the whole word.” (p.292); “Words carrying the two higher tones 1 and 2, have clear voice quality, words in the low tones have a breathy voice qualty.” (p.292) The opposition between aspirated and non-aspirated consonants is not found under the two lower tones, and the archiphonemic series in that position is pronounced unaspirated with a slight optional voicing. This correlation derives from the origin of the tonal system. the devoicing of an old voiced series in Proto-Tamang which merged with an old voiceless unaspirated series, gave rise to the two low tones through a process of merger and compensatory split of the old two-tone system (Mazaudon 1977, 1978a).” (pp. 292-3)

othernotes: cf. Awa, Kewa; only codas are m, n, ? (no velar nasal in lg)
reference: Frantz, Chester I. & Majorie E. 1966. Gadsup phonemes and toneme units. Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 5, 1-11. Canberra: Linguistic Circle of Canberra Publications. Series A. Occasional Papers #7. (Also in McKaughan, 406-413)

citefor: exx. of prefinal contours; realization of contours LM/MH and ML/HM; initial pause = %L; L absorb; stress based on tone and vowel quality and presence or absence of onset (p.9)
